xxl.core.cursors.groupers
Class DBScan

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor
      xxl.core.cursors.groupers.DBScan
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator, Cursor
public class DBScan
extends AbstractCursor

A grouper that generates clusters from a given input iteration. So, each call to the next method returns a new cursor representing a new cluster. This cursor is based on the DBScan algorithm published in "A Density-Based Algorithm for Discovering Clusters in Large Spatial Databases with Noise" ([EKS+96]) and "Incremental Clustering for Mining in a Data Warehousing Environment" ([EKS+98]). But the algorithm is modified in a way, that the computation of the clusters and their elements is implemented absolutely lazy.

"The key idea is that for each point of a cluster the neighborhood concerning a given radius has to contain at least a minimum number of points, i.e. the density in the neighborhood has to exceed some threshold." ([EKS+96])

IMPORTANT: All objects of the given input iterator have to implement the classifiable interface.

Note: If the input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

Example usage: 

     // get the data; here the data is contained in a list-bag
     
     Iterator input = data.cursor();
 
     // using an Euclidean metric as distance function
     // eps = 1.6
     // minPts = 3
 
                DBScan clusterCursor = new DBScan(
                        input,
                        1.6,
                        3,
                        new AbstractFunction() {
                                public Object invoke(Object descriptor) {
                                        final Sphere sphere = (Sphere)descriptor;
                                        return data.query(  // define a simple range query: iterating over all elements
                                                new AbstractPredicate() { // and checking if the given point is contained in the search sphere
                                                        public boolean invoke(Object o) {
                                                                return sphere.contains(
                                                                        new Sphere(((ClassifiableObject)o).getObject(), 0d, null)
                                                                );
                                                        }
                                                }
                                        );
                                }
                        },
                        new AbstractFunction() {
                                public Object invoke(Object object, Object eps) {
                                        return new Sphere(((ClassifiableObject)object).getObject(), ((Double)eps).doubleValue(), null);
                                }
                        }
                );
                
                clusterCursor.open();

                for (int i = 0; clusterCursor.hasNext(); i++) {
                        Cursor next = (Cursor)clusterCursor.next(); // each element of the clusterCursor is a new cursor, namely a new cluster
                        System.out.println("cluster " + i + ": ");
                        Cursors.println(next);
                }
                
                clusterCursor.close();
To perform a more efficient clustering, the range queries have to use an index-structure, e.g. an M-tree, where the data, i.e. the classifiable objects, are located in.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, Classifiable, Distance

Field Detail

eps

protected double eps
The search 'radius' used for the range queries.

minPts

protected int minPts
The minimum number of elements that have to be positioned in the Eps-neighborhood of an element.

input

protected Cursor input
The input iteration providing the data to be grouped.

queue

protected Queue queue
This queue contains all elements that are already belonging to a cluster, but a range query has to be performed with them.

noiseQueue

protected Queue noiseQueue
This queue contains all elements that have been marked as noise. Due to performance reasons the implementation of this DBScan algorithm does not delete elements, that were inserted into the noise-cluster, but later are assigned to a special cluster. Therefore this queue may contain elements that have already been returned to the user with regard to another cluster. When returning the noise, i.e. the last cluster, all elements that have a different clusterID will be filtered out.

changedCIDQueue

protected Queue changedCIDQueue
This queue contains all elements that belonged to the noise-cluster, but which were assigned later to a special cluster. So, the clusterID of these elements changed.

rangeQuery

protected Function rangeQuery
A unary function that internally holds a data structure, e.g. an index, to perform range queries efficiently. The argument of this function should be a kind of an arbitrary descriptor and its result should be a cursor of objects implementing the classifiable interface. 
     f : Object (Descriptor) --> Cursor of ClassifiableObjects

getDescriptor

protected Function getDescriptor
A binary function returning a kind of descriptor used for the range query. To determine this descriptor the function gets two arguments, namely the search object and a user-defined radius eps. 
     f : Object x eps --> Object (Descriptor)

nextCluster

protected Cursor nextCluster
An internal used cursor representing the next cluster to be returned to the user by a call to the next or peek method.

CLUSTER_NO

protected long CLUSTER_NO
The cluster number with which the elements will be marked during the algorithms execution.

NOISE

public static final int NOISE
A constant cluster number for noise.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

UNDEFINED

public static final int UNDEFINED
A constant cluster number for a cluster that is undefined, e.g., at the start of the algorithm.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

isUnclassified

Returns an unary predicate that verifies if a given classifiable object is already classified.

Returns an unary predicate that verifies if a given classifiable object is marked as noise.

Constructor Detail

DBScan

public DBScan(java.util.Iterator input,
              double eps,
              int minPts,
              Function rangeQuery,
              Function getDescriptor,
              Function newQueue,
              Function newNoiseQueue,
              Function newChangedCIDQueue)
       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new lazy DBScan cluster operator.

Parameters:
input - the input iteration providing the data to be grouped.
eps - the eps-radius used for range queries.
minPts - the minimum number of elements that have to be located in the eps-neighborhood of a core point.
rangeQuery - a function performing a range query based on a given descriptor.
getDescriptor - a function delivering a kind of descriptor for a range query.
newQueue - a parameterless function returning a new queue used for storing elements with which a range query will be performed.
newNoiseQueue - a parameterless function delivering a new queue holding the noise.
newChangedCIDQueue - a parameterless function returning a queue that gets the elements that belonged to noise, but later are assigned to a special cluster.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a negative value for eps or minPts has been specified.

DBScan

public DBScan(java.util.Iterator input,
              double eps,
              int minPts,
              Function rangeQuery,
              Function getDescriptor)
       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new lazy DBScan cluster operator. Uses a stack-queue for storing the elements range queries will be performed with, a list-queue for noise and a default FIFO-queue for the elements that changed from the noise cluster to an other cluster.

Parameters:
input - the input iteration providing the data to be grouped.
eps - the eps-radius used for range queries.
minPts - the minimum number of elements that have to be located in the eps-neighborhood of a core point.
rangeQuery - a function performing a range query based on a given descriptor.
getDescriptor - a function delivering a kind of descriptor for a range query.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a negative value for eps or minPts has been specified.
Method Detail

ClusterID_FACTORY

public static Function ClusterID_FACTORY(long clusterID)
Returns an unary function that can be used to mark classifiable objects with regard to assign them to a user-defined cluster.

Parameters:
clusterID - the clusterID determining to which cluster the objects should be assigned to.
Returns:
an unary function that can be used to mark classifiable objects with regard to assign them to a user-defined cluster.

open

public void open()
Opens the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor

close

public void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close queues, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected java.lang.Object nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the DBScan-cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the DBScan-cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the DBScan-cursor, otherwise false.
